title: Using Mathematica to generate logo(type)s
content: I admit I don’t quite know what to make of this [blog post](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019194230/http:/blog.wolfram.com/2009/02/26/exploring-logo-designs-with-mathematica/ "Exploring logo designs with Mathematica") concerning the use of math software Mathematica to redesign logotypes and find fonts of matching weights.
author: joeclark

comments.content: Think of it in terms of what mathematicians simply enjoy doing. It's not going to have any appreciable impact on graphic design in the long run, I shouldn't think!

I could see Target doing this to produce even more permutations of its already versatile and malleable logo to play with in advertising and on packaging. A record, book, or game publisher could slap a new permutation on every release. It could make an entire product line collectible. And a blog could explain the math behind every permutation. Sort of like what Fossil has done with all of its logos over the years, but nerdier and without so much drawing.
